conclusion: To determine the speed of the elevator at t = 60 seconds, we need to analyze the given acceleration-displacement graph and integrate the acceleration over time to find the velocity.
The graph shows the acceleration (a) as a function of time (t).
Positive acceleration indicates upward motion. Negative acceleration indicates downward motion (deceleration or downward acceleration).

premise: The integral of acceleration over time gives the change in velocity.
conclusion: To find the velocity (v), we need to integrate the acceleration with respect to time.
Initially, the elevator starts from rest, so v0 = 0.

The segments of acceleration are: 0 ≤ t < 1 seconds: +2 m/s², 1 ≤ t < 4 seconds: +2 m/s², 4 ≤ t < 5 seconds: -2 m/s², 5 ≤ t < 55 seconds: 0 m/s², 55 ≤ t < 56 seconds: -2 m/s², 56 ≤ t < 59 seconds: 0 m/s², 59 ≤ t ≤ 60 seconds: -2 m/s².
The speed of the elevator at t = 60 seconds is 10 m/s.
